I somewhat doubt that you need me to tell you what this is about, but just in case you forgot: you've got a blacksmith's apprentice (Orlando Bloom), a governor's daughter (Keira Knightly), and a scoundrel pirate (Johnny Depp).  Their paths are on a collision course, and when you add undead pirates with hurt feelings to the equation, that will only complicate the situation.  I've been meaning to rewatch this one for a minute because it is so much fun.  You can say what you want about the sequels; I personally think they have their moments, especially Dead Man's Chest, but I understand why people view them as fodder for the Hollywood blockbuster machine.  With The Curse of the Black Pearl, I doubt you will find many out there who want to argue a case against it.  Now, as you may already be aware, this is a movie that is based on a Disney theme park ride.  Not many movies originate from park attractions, and even fewer are worth talking about, but the first Pirates is the exception to the rule.  Appropriately enough, the movie itself feels like an exciting ride, and there are very few lulls to be found from start to finish.  The pacing is dynamite, and even though the runtime is approaching two and a half hours, you don't feel it since there is perpetual forward movement.  Pirates made a huge imprint on pop culture, and for better or worse, it unlocked the quirky performance library of Johnny Depp.  It's arguably his most iconic role to date, and you can tell he had the best time making this movie.  Bloom and Knightley also bring a lot to the table, but I think it is Geoffrey Rush as the main antagonist Barbossa that doesn't get nearly enough credit for his performance.  He always feels like a threat, and whenever he pops up, you're just waiting to hear what he will say next.  When I think of movies that aim to entertain, this is one of the most successful movies out there.  It has so much natural charisma that it is just downright infectious to watch.  It's so much fun to watch allegiances shift on a dime, and it has the perfect energy that you want to see in a blockbuster.  I will say that the CGI hasn't aged the best, which is a little tough because it is so reliant on the special effects for these ghost pirates.  It can also be tough to get this to the television as often as I would like because of the longer runtime, even though I wouldn't cut anything out.  Still, those are minor quibbles for an otherwise massively pleasing megahit.

Wow, I was not expecting the movie to start out with such a bang. So much atmosphere and tension. I love it. This is of course back when Disney was on top of their game. Fantastic use of imagery, the cinematography is insanely good and well thought out. Beautiful use of lighting. I love how they cut to Elizabeth waking up right after she sees the ghostly pirate ship in her dreams. Pretty spooky. It keeps you anticipating and interested. The CGI is actually impressive, especially for its time. This movie has a very cheeky and silly sense of humor. What an iconic character, I honestly can't see anyone else playing Jack Sparrow other than Johnny Depp. He is Jack Sparrow. He really does have a knack for clever and witty humor. It's impressive how well they nail the whole look, style and aesthetic of the 1700's. It almost feels like I'm watching a movie that takes place in the world of Assassin's Creed Black Flag. Plenty of exciting moments keep it from becoming boring or bland. The sword duels and ship fights being one of them. The whole movie has a great comedic flair to it. The set pieces and designs are wonderfully crafted. 

Unfortunately, this is one of those movies where if you've seen it once, you've seen it a hundred times. The story isn't really anything special that leaves you thinking after the credits roll, it's more of a ride that you enjoy taking part in. It felt like the movie could've benefitted if it had cut a couple of scenes short or had not shown them at all. It felt like the pacing was excellent at the beginning but then towards the middle, it lagged a bit, showing scenes that we didn't necessarily need. If they would've shortened the movie to about 1 hour 50 something or close to the 2 hour mark, I think it would've been better. 

Overall, it's a fun adventure pirate movie with exciting sequences, funny moments, tight camera work and one of the most iconic characters, and that's really it. The story didn't really wow me, it felt kind of vapid, and some of the characters felt bland since there wasn't any interesting character development going on. But more than anything, it was too long. I would recommend it, but I think everyone and their grandma has seen it already.

Gore Verbinski's romantic fantasy swashbuckler Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) is a fast paced blast of constant laughter and exciting action. Gore Verbinski's direction incredibly balances slap stick and witty humor alongside daring adventure. His unique vision of funny comedy, tender romance, and scary horror elements work wonders for Pirates of the Caribbean as a quick corsair adventure that any family can watch. Gore Verbinski is an excellent director with a real style and atmosphere that contributes a genuine love of sailing, pirates, and swashbuckling to this film full of sword fights and cannonfire.

Johnny Depp is phenomenal as the likable Captain Jack Sparrow, who outwits his enemies all over the high seas. He's funny and endearing, so much so that you always root for Jack to get out of all his precarious nautical situations. Geoffrey Rush is outstanding as Captain Hector Barbossa with his cheery pirate laugh, gnarly speech, and intimidating presence. Orlando Bloom is cool as a blacksmith turned pirate for the sake of love named Will Turner. He's an endearing lead actor with a fun chemistry alongside Johnny Depp's Captain Jack Sparrow.

Keira Knightley is wicked as the fiery Miss Elizabeth Swann. Her sense of adventure and mischief are obvious thanks to Knightley's spirited performance as Pirates of the Caribbean's leading lady. Miss Swann is simply a wonderfully complex character.

Jack Davenport is aptly prudish and stuffy as the British Commodore James Norrington. Jonathan Pryce is funny as the traditional family values loving Governor Weatherby Swann. Kevin McNally is entertaining as the steadfast first mate to Captain Jack Sparrow called Joshamee Gibbs. He's a likable staple of the series alongside David Bailie's mute and parroted Cotton. Zoe Saldana is great as the feisty Anamaria. I wish they used her more throughout the Pirates franchise.

I must mention how hilarious Lee Arenberg is as the stout and grumpy Pintel. He's quite imposing in this first one with perfect line delivery for "hello poppet." I adore Mackenzie Crook's portrayal of the gaunt and gangly pirate Ragetti. Crook is hilarious with his endless literary references, false eye, and good nature. I should also shout out Giles New and Angus Barnett's as the two argumentative Navy guards Murtogg and Mullroy, respectively. They are such a funny comedy relief pairing akin to Arenberg and Crook's Pintel and Ragetti.

Dariusz Wolski's cinematography looks breathtaking for every wide shot of the ocean, a sunrise, or pirates advancing. His panning shots sweep around the swordplay to make every action scene riveting and enthralling to watch! Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio's script is fantastic with clever jokes that make Captain Jack Sparrow a hilarious hero and a cunning foe for the Royal Navy to contend with constantly. Their story is phenomenal as they tell a compelling tale about greedy pirates cursed by Aztec gold on a quest for their salvation. That is just as engaging as a young blacksmith's journey into piracy alongside a vetern, disgraced pirate captain to save his bonnie lass.

Arthur Schmidt, Stephen E. Rivkin, and Craig Wood's editing makes Pirates of the Caribbean a brisk 143 minute epic adventure that never gets old. Klaus Badelt's score is unforgettable. Hans Zimmer always gets the credit for composing the Pirates of the Caribbean's music, but Klaus Badelt actually made the music for The Curse of the Black Pearl. It's exhilarating and inspiring with memorable melodies and pulsing rhythms. Penny Rose's pirate costumes look realistic and period correct with tons of added details that make each character look unique. Ve Neill's make-up is excellent and intriguing as he gives each pirate their own style in appearance.

The CGI was groundbreaking for the cursed skeleton pirates in the moonlight that still looks amazing. Brian Morris' production design is astounding in that they built real pirate ships and large galleons for the sets. All the practical stunts and minimal use of special effects makes Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl timeless. This is how adventure blockbusters should be crafted by a loving crew.

The aristocratic Elizabeth Swann, Keira Knightley, saves the poor Will Turner, Orlando Bloom, by taking his medallion and he goes on to become a blacksmith. She encounters the alcoholic pirate Captain Jack Sparrow, when she accidentally falls into the water and he rescues her but he is arrested when her husband discovers him. She is later captured by an enemy ship but due to a case of mistaken identity she finds herself being used to ward off a curse that has befallen them. Turner has fallen in love with her and enlists Sparrow to help recapture her but he sets his sights on recapturing his former ship "The Black Pearl" that he held great affection for. Swann enjoys her new lifestyle greatly and is happy to be caught up in the conflict between Sparrow and his enemies. Swann is exchanged various times between the two sides and briefly flirts with Sparrow but ultimately ends up with Turner who fights for her and presents as a far more attractive love interest than the older drunk who may be a great pirate but lacks charm.

Knightley was the stand out from the film to me as she has star power in spades and some of the talent that she would put to great use in later films like Atonement (2007) and Anna Karenina (2012) shines through her. She was certainly cast for her beauty and cut glass accent, traits that fit an unattainable but appealing society beauty well, yet she brings more to the role than another sex symbol from this era would have. There is a joy and a liveliness to her performance that is lacking in Bloom's effort and when you see her pick up a sword and beginning to thrust and parry you do find her somewhat convincing. She has touches of Olivia de Havilland in Captain Blood (1935) and while this film is considerably lesser than that Errol Flynn classic her capable love interest does give the film some flavor. In the era of Michael Bay films that shamelessly ogled women who served purely as sex objects there is a novelty to seeing a capable actress bring some attitude to an underwritten role and make us genuinely care about at least one of the characters in the film.

Issues with the film include the fact that Sparrow is unlikable and hard to care about and Bloom is so bland that he fails as the hot young leading man. "Even I love Johnny Depp, and I'm male," a previous reviewer declares, tongue in cheek. Well, I wouldn't go quite that far, but there's no doubt whatsoever that when I lost my heart to this film, Johnny Depp's outrageous Cap'n Jack Sparrow had almost everything to do with it. I don't normally review 'current' films, so the very fact that I'm writing this highlights an almost unprecedented event - after endless failures, Hollywood has finally rediscovered the spirit of the classic swashbuckler movie.

With hindsight, I think the one brilliant decision that was made at some point - given a modern production environment - was to *separate the roles* of hero and swashbuckler. You can then have your worthy Costner-type juvenile lead, as required, who has to Come To Terms with his Past (although his eventual fate is a trifle unexpected in conventional terms...) - *but* you can also have your essential and irrepressible swaggering rogue (of course, he totally steals the film from the moment he first appears, but *that's* no hardship!)

The moonlight special effects were overdone, in my opinion - not that they aren't believable, but that they would have been more effective if used more sparingly, for occasional flashes of nastiness rather than solid minutes of battle. However, that's a minor niggle. The stunts are energetic, highly satisfactory, *not* computerised, and on occasion even carried out by the stars :-)

The other saving grace of the production is its humour - not that there aren't a few over-arch knowing references, but on the whole it manages to send itself up without suspending disbelief in the process. Jack Sparrow's first arrival on the scene (with total aplomb aboard a steadily-sinking boat) is a prime example, as indeed are the vast majority of subsequent scenes involving this character...

The basic Romance and Rescue structure is satisfactory enough, with the addition of the requisite Feisty Female for the 21st century (though I felt the character would have been a little more historically plausible if she had been a little less liberated - she clearly possesses a stronger character than her young man, she doesn't have to strive to be his physical equal as well...) However, it is the pirates themselves who really make the film, simply by being a pack of unreconstructed and uninhibited villains (from the Jeffrey Farnol School of Historical Dialect) who are far larger than life and totally unselfconscious about it. To quote the opening words of the 'Guardian' review: "we have been waiting [50 years] for a modern pirate film featuring someone who, in all seriousness, actually says the words, or perhaps the two-syllable single word: 'Ah-harrrrr!'"

Jack Sparrow, as swashbuckler extraordinaire and consummate rogue (of course, totally honest in his own way... ahem) is the main attraction of the entire film. Not so much loopy as totally round the bend - outrageous and unpredictable (there is a running gag throughout the first part of the film where he is repeatedly described as "the worst pirate I've ever seen", as in "the worst at it", only for the preposterous tactics in question to prove spectacularly successful).

This character saves the hero in more ways than one - without him, the film would be another "Mask of Zorro", a rather stodgy attempt to update an old favourite for modern-day sensibilities and compensate with more and flashier sword-fighting (swashbuckling is not *about* fighting! It comes into it, yes, but it's not the point.) But together, the pair work off one another beautifully - reliability and inspired lunacy, self-doubt and cocky flamboyance, dogged devotion and shameless self-interest. The only question is which, precisely, is the sidekick...

There are two beginnings to this film, neither of them bearing any relation to the wooden costume-drama-by-numbers prologue that actually opens the movie. The moment when events start to move (it could scarcely be less subtle) is signalled by the swell of the theme music for the first time at Sparrow's initial appearance. But for me the moment when the film really took off was in that instant during his first escape, when he seizes the rope and swings up, up, and out, in a classic swashbuckler move from the past that brought it all flooding back... and my heart flew up after him into my throat, and remained enjoyably in that position until the end of the movie, when the audience began spontaneously to applaud.

The film is far from perfect - characters like Captain Norrington (*please* - 'Commodore', like 'Prime Minister', is a job description, not a form of address!) and the Governor are little more than pantomime stereotypes, with only frustrating hints of humanity to indicate that they do after all have potential denied them by the script. Annoying anachronisms slip in - "it's okay", "I was rooting for you" - most of the nautical jargon comes out with about as much sign of comprehension as a phonetic rendition of a foreign language, and Sparrow's one precious charge of powder gets soaked through often enough in the course of the plot to be utterly useless by the end. Both hero and heroine come across as wooden and thankless roles. Orlando Bloom may be costumed to look increasingly like Errol Flynn during the course of the film (was it my imagination, or does he spend it gradually cultivating a duplicate of that famous moustache?), but, alas, any resemblance ends there.

But then it doesn't really matter. It is Depp, not Bloom, who has inherited the mantle of Flynn and Fairbanks in this film. Once again, the children were wondering, "What's up with Daddy? Is he OK?"

Perhaps I am just losing my grip, having an adolescent movie get to me this way. But when those final credits roll, and Captain Jack narrows his eyes and says, "Now, bring me that horizon. Drink up me hearties, yo ho" and the music swells ... it is difficult to put into words the effect it has.

At this point my children have to yank me forcibly from the theater, lest I persist in watching the credits to the bitter end, and bid good-bye to the little monkey once more, wiping tears of exultation from my eyes.

This is not just another "entry" in the summer blockbust sweepstakes. It is an exquisite work of fantasy and inventiveness, a true classic, on the order of "The Wizard of Oz." I do hope Depp's performance garners not just awards, but a place in the pantheon, something we old fogies -- and our gently fogeying children decades hence -- will show to our children and grandchildren like a revealed treasure. What has now become a multi-billion-dollar franchise once started as an ambitious risk by Disney.  Make a feature length film based on a ride at your theme park?  That just didn't seem like something logical to do at the time.  However, with a talented group of actors, a swashbuckling script, and one hell of a musical score, the first Pirates of the Caribbean is an absolute joy on all fronts.  Perhaps, never really being topped in any way by its successors.

Starting a new franchise is bold these days, which is why Disney made the right move in hiring Johnny Depp as the charming and sometimes irreverent Captain Jack Sparrow.  An even better move was not leaving the entire film up to Sparrow to lead.  Complementing the zaniness of Sparrow is the elegant but fierce Elizabeth Swan and the mysterious and brave Will Turner (played by Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom respectively).  All of them are great, but may not prove to be as fun if not for the incredible visual effects, makeup, and action.  This felt like the first major blockbuster of the 21st century, and the rest of the series certainly ranks up there.

One of the best things this series, and particularly the first film, did so well is create a mythology and universe surrounding Pirates in and around the Caribbean.  It happens gradually in 'Black Pearl', seemingly allowing viewers to adapt to the unknown shores of the series without feeling overwhelmed.  A lot of it's fun swordplay and grim family history, but the supernatural elements play just as well.  Immortally cursed pirates just begin to mark the lovable weirdness of this film.

Almost as well known as the characters and the film itself is the score by Klaus Badelt and Hans Zimmer.  Zimmer is always remembered as the one who created the iconic theme, but Badelt should also be credited, as should a few other unknown composers at the time who chipped in.  But really, the movies would not be the same without the perfect music played over the action and adventures.  

This film is lengthy and does feature an annoyingly pesky English Navy who won't go away, but Geoffrey Rush's turn as Captain Barbosa and an equally (if not more) memorable turn from Depp as Sparrow makes the first film the best in the series.  As fun as the action and over-the-top humor and adventure are, the thing you can always come back to in these films are the characters.  The movies never quite captured the same entertainment as 'Black Pearl' did, but that wasn't for lack of trying.
